title: 5 GHz VS 2 GHz
content: 5 GHz higher bandwidth, more channels and less crowded than 2.4 GHz, but range lower. 2.4 GHz range higher but slower bandwidth, fewer channels and more crowded.

title: 2019-ESE-Q1
content:
Figure 1 shows 4 PCs (PC1, PC2, PC3 and PC4) with their MAC addresses shown are connected to a switch. Currently, the switch has only 1 entry in its MAC address table.



Please refer to Figure 1 for all the following questions.
  1. What happens to the Switch MAC address table when PC4 sends a frame addressed to PC3?
    2. The MAC address table will be updated with the MAC address of PC4 and its connected port.
  2. What action will the switch do when PC3 sends a frame addressed to PC1?
    3. The switch will flood this frame to all other ports (1, 4, 12)
  3. What destination MAC address will PC2 use to send a frame to all the PCs?
    4. The destination MAC address is the broadcast address FFFF.FFFF.FFFF

title: 802.11 Standards
content: 802.11 - 2.4 GHz, up to 2 Mbps. 802.11a - 5 GHz, up to 54 Mbps, small coverage, not interoperable w. 802.11b and 802.11g. 802.11b - 2.4 GHz, up to 11 Mbps, longer range than 802.11a. 802.11g - 2.4 GHz, up to 54 Mbps, backwards compatible w. 802.11b w. reduced bandwidth capacity. 802.11n - 2.4 & 5 GHz, range from 150 Mbps to 600 Mbps, up to 70m range, APs & clients need multiple antennas using MIMO technology, backwards compatible w. 802.11a/b/g devices w. limiting data rates. 802.11ac - 5 GHz, range from 450 Mbps to 1.3 Gbps using MIMO technology, backwards compatible with 802.11a/n devices. 802.11ax - 2.4 & 5 GHz, a.k.a. Wi-Fi 6 or High-Efficiency Wireless (HEW), better power efficncy., higher data rates, handle many devices. Will use 1 & 7 GHz when available.

title: 802.1X
content: Client - Supplicant, Switch - Authenticator, Authentication Server

title: A company uses a cloud-based payroll system. Which cloud computing technology is this company using?
content: Software as a service (SaaS)

title: AAA
content: Authentication, Authorization, Accounting.  Authentication - Usernames and passwords to verify the user's identity. Authorization - Controls what users can and cannot do on the network. Accounting - Collects and reports usage data, for auditing or billing. Uses TACAS+ and RADIUS to authenticate users on a central db.

title: Access Internet
content: Any address with the 10 in the first octet (e.g. 10.0.10.0) is private IPv4 and need to use Network Address Translation (NAT) to convert private IPv4 address to internet-routable IPv4 addresses.

title: Access port
content: A switch port that sends and expects traffic with no VLAN tag. Only for 1 vlan.port send/expects to receive tagged traffic.

title: Advantage of Cisco Router as relay agent
content: Provides relay services for multiple UDP services, e.g. Port 37 Times, Port 53 DNS, etc.

title: Alleviate Network Congestion
content:
Fast port speeds - more data transfer per second, but more expensive; Fast internal switching - fast internal bus or shared memory; Large frame buffers - Store more frames instead of drop them, good for duplex mismatch. High port density - more ports, local traffic, less switches needed, less collisions.
Related questions:
  • Which switch characteristic helps keep traffic local and alleviates network congestion?

title: AP Broadcast Frame
content: AP may regularly broadcast beacons. Probing, authentication and association frames are used only during association/reassociation process.

title: AP Discovery
content: A wireless NIC will send probe requests and receive broadcast beacon frames to discover an AP.

title: AP Modes
content: Passive - AP periodically sends broadcast beacon frames containing SSID, supported standards, security settings. Active - Hidden and clients need to know the name of the SSID. Client sends a probe request.

title: Auto-MDIX
content:
Auto configures the port to allow device connections to use either straight-through or crossover cable.
Turn on MDIX (interface config): auto mdix
Display info about auto-MDIX setting: show controllers ethernet-controller phy

title: Before creating WLAN
content: Create a new VLAN interface. Each WLAN on Cisco 3500 WLC needs its own VLAN interface.

title: Benefits of cloud computing and virtualization
content:
• Provides a "pay-as-you-go" model, allowing organizations to treat computing and storage expenses as a utility
  • Enables rapid responses to increasing data volume requirements
  • Company does not need to be concerned about how to handle increasing data storage and processing demands with in-house data center equipment.
  • Company can increase processing and storage capacity as needed and then decrease capacity when it is no longer needed.

title: Best Practice - CDP & LLDP
content: Disable both protocols on interfaces where they are not required.

title: Best Practice - Home WAP
content: Wireless network password, AP password, SSID

title: Blocked ports
content: Not root nor designated port so, blocked.

title: Boot Sequence
content:
Power-on self-test (POST) > Boot Loader > CPU init. > Flash memory init. > BOOT environment variable locates IOS, IOS takes over.
Related questions:
  • What does a switch use to locate and load the IOS image?

title: BPDU
content: Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs) share info about themselves and their connections and are used to elect the root port.

title: Bridge ID (BID) Components
content: REDIRECT:Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDU)

title: Bridge Priority Value
content:
Part of the BPDU, used to determine the root bridge. Available values range from 0 to 61440 in increments of 4096. The switch with the lowest priority value becomes the root bridge.
If the bridge priority across switchees is the same, the switch with the lowest MAC address becomes the root bridge.

title: Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDU)
content: Bridge Priority (4 bits), Extended System ID (12 bits), MAC Address (48 bits). See Root Bridge Election

title: Broadcast Address (MAC address)
content: FFFF.FFFF.FFFF

title: Broadcast Domain
content:
Where broadcast frames will reach. L2 switches, hubs and bridges extend the broadcast domain. Routers divide domains since they block broadcasts. Link between routers counts as broadcast domain.

Too many broadcasts may cause congestion and poor network performance.

title: Broadcast Storm
content: Abnormally high number of broadcasts overwhelming the network during a specific amount of time.

title: CAPWAP
content: IEEE standard procotol, provides encapsulation & forwarding of wireless user traffic btwn AP and WLC.

title: Channel
content: Adjusting channels is to avoid interference from nearby wireless devices. 1, 6 and 11 are good because they are 5 channels apart, minimising interference with other channels. Channel range is 1-11.

title: Characteristic of MIB
content: OIDs are organized in a hierarchical structure.

title: Check IP address that is assigned to MAC address
content: show ip dhcp binding (See show ip dhcp binding for more info)

title: Cisco Discovery Protocol (CDP)
content: Cisco proprietary Layer 2 protocol that used to gather information about directly connected Cisco neighbour device. CDP ads R sent occasionally, which contains info about device(s) discovered,  device name & number + type of interface on device.

title: Cloud Models (Types of clouds)
content:
Public CloudPrivate CloudHybrid CloudCommunity Cloud
Provides services and applications to the general population. Services may be free or offered on a pay-per-use model, such as online storage.Provides services and applications to a specific organization and may be set up within the private organization or managed by an outside organization.Made up of two or more clouds, where each part remains a separate object, but both are connected using a single architecture. People have diff access based on user rights.Created for exclusive use by a specific community. Difference with public clouds is that it has been customized for the community.

title: Collision Domain
content: Only when half duplex is used. Collision happens on half duplex side. Hub increases collision domain, while switches, routers and bridges divide collision domains. To alleviate network congestion due to collisions, use a high port density switch (see Alleviate Network Congestion)

title: Command History Features
content:
• Set the command history buffer size.
  • Recall previously entered commands.

Related questions:
  • Which tasks can be accomplished by using the command history feature? (Choose two.)

title: Configure EtherChannel (LACP)
content:
Enter configuration of the interface range.Switch(config)# interface range <list of interfaces> (E.g. Fa0/2,Fa0/4)
Configure channel groupSwitch(config-if-range)# channel-group <group number> mode active

(After this, you will most likely need to configure trunking. See Configure Trunking)

title: Configure Router-on-a-Stick Inter-VLAN routing
content:
Enter subinterface configuration.R1(config)# interface G0/0/1.<VLAN ID> (E.g. G0/0/1.10)
Provide description (optional)R1(config-subif)# Description Default Gateway for VLAN 10
Set the encapsulation mode.R1(config-subif)# encapsulation dot1Q 10 (10 represents VLAN 10, set accordingly)
Set IP address of subinterface.R1(config-subif)# ip address <ip address> <subnet mask>
Enter interface configuration mode for the interface serving the subinterfaces.R1(config-subif)# exit
R1(config)# interface G0/0/1
Switch on the port interface.R1(config-if)# no shut

title: Configure SSH
content:
1. Verify SSH support by using show ip ssh.
  2. Config IP domain by using ip domain-name
  3. Generate RSA key pairs by using cypto key generate rsa
  4. Config user authentication by using username secret
  5. Config vty lines by going to vty config using line vty 0 15 then type transport input ssh, then login local

Related questions:
  • When configuring a switch for SSH access, what other command that is associated with the login local command is required to be entered on the switch?

title: Configure Trunking (Trunk Configuration Commands)
content:
Enter global configuration mode.Switch# configure terminal
Enter interface configuration mode.Switch(config)# interface interface-id (if you configured EtherChannel, use "port-channel <channel number>". e.g., interface port-channel 1)
Set the port to permanent trunking mode.Switch(config-if)# switchport mode trunk
Sets the native VLAN to something other than VLAN 1.Switch(config-if)# switchport trunk native vlan vlan-id
Specify the list of VLANs to be allowed on the trunk link.Switch(config-if)# switchport trunk allowed vlan vlan-list
Return to the privileged EXEC mode.Switch(config-if)# end

title: Configuring a router as a DHCP client
content: Enter the interface to configure, then type ip address dhcp

title: Content Addressable Memory (CAM) table
content:
As the switch learns the relationship of ports to devices, it builds a MAC address table. This table is stored in CAM which is a special type of memory used in high-speed searching applications. For this reason, the MAC address table is sometimes also called the CAM table.

CAM is significantly faster than RAM, as it searches the entire memory content in one cycle, instead of a single address at a time. However, CAM is more expensive than RAM.

title: Create/Configure
content: For VLAN, go to VLAN Creation. For others, check the bottom. For steps before creating WLAN, see Before creating WLAN.

title: Cut-Through Switching
content:
Frames are forwarded without any error checking.
Can do rapid frame switching and has lower latency than Store-and-Forward switching. Once the destination MAC address of the frame has been looked up, forwarding decisions can be made. However due to no FCS check, invalid frames may be forwarded.

title: Data formats (JSON XML YAML)
content:
The common data formats that are used in many applications including network automation and programmability are as follows:
  • JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) - In JSON, the data known as an object is one or more key/value pairs enclosed in braces { }. Keys must be strings within double quotation marks " ". Keys and values are separated by a colon.
  • eXtensible Markup Language (XML) - In XML, the data is enclosed within a related set of tags data.
  • YAML Ain't Markup Language (YAML) - A superset of JSON. In YAML, the data known as an object is one or more key value pairs. Key value pairs are separated by a colon without the use of quotation marks. YAML uses indentation to define its structure, without the use of brackets or commas.

Related questions:
  • Discuss the three data formats covered in class and their readability attributes.
  • What is YAML?

title: Designated Port
content: When There is a Root Port If one end of a segment is a root port, then the other end is a designated port.

title: Designated Port When There is No Root Port
content: Leaves segments between two switches where both switches is not the root bridge. Theport on the switch with the least-cost path to the root bridge is the designated port.

title: Designated Ports on Root Bridge
content: All ports on the root bridge are designated ports. This is because the root bridge has the lowest cost to itself.

title: DHCP Client Boot Up
content: A DHCP enabled client PC will send two broadcast messages - DHCPDISCOVER and DHCPREQUEST (see DHCPv4 Operation)

title: DHCP Port Number
content: 67 and 68 (if there's only 1 option select 67)

title: DHCP Starvation Attack
content: Legitimate users will not be able to get valid IP addresses, Layer 2 attack.

title: DHCPv4 Operation
content: Client sends Discover broadcast to find a DHCP server (DHCPDISCOVER) > Server responds init. request and sends Offer (DHCPOFFER) > Client accepts and sends Request (DHCPREQUEST) > Server confirms lease and sends DHCP Acknowledgement (DHCPACK)

title: DHCPv4 Relay
content: In the interface to the network, type ip helper-address <ip address of DHCP server>. Verify using show ip interface.

title: DHCPv6 Relay
content: In the interface to the network, type ipv6 dhcp relay destination ipv6-address [interface]. To verify, type show ipv6 dhcp interface.

title: DHCPv6 Server Types
content: Stateless - Enabled in RA messages with the ipv6 nd other-config-flag command. Clients send only DHCPv6 INFORMATION REQUEST msgs. Enabled on client using ipv6 address autoconfig command.

title: DHCPv6 Server Types
content: Stateful - M flag is 1 in RA msgs, uses address command to create pool of addresses, enabled on client using ipv6 address dhcp

title: Disable DTP
content: On links where trunking is not intended and when a Cisco switch is connected to a non-Cisco switch. See nonegotiate.

title: DTP (Dynamic Trunking Protocol)
content:
Cisco proprietary protocol, used to auto negotiate trunking with another device. Links dynamically attempt trunking. Do not use for non-Cisco switches.

If dynamic auto is used in one interface, the other interface must be either dynamic desirable or trunk in order to form a trunk. (Not to be confused with LACP/PAgP)

DTP modes

  • access: Interface becomes nontrunk interface, and negotiates to convert the link into a nontrunk link.
  • dynamic desirable: Actively attempts to convert link to trunk
  • dynamic auto: Passively waits for neighbour to initiate trunking
  • trunk: Puts the interface into permanent trunking mode and negotiates to convert the neighboring link into a trunk link. Interface becomes trunk interface even if the neighboring interface is not a trunk interface.
To configure a negotiated interface, in the interface config, type the command: Switch(config-if)# switchport mode {access | dynamic {auto | desirable} | trunk}
To enable trunking from a Cisco switch to a device that does not support DTP, use the commands: switchport mode trunk and switchport nonegotiate in the interface configuration.

title: DTP modes
content: REDIRECT:DTP (Dynamic Trunking Protocol)

title: Duplex
content: If one side is full & other is half, late collision occurs on the half side. To config full duplex, use duplex full in interface config.

title: Duplex Mismatch
content:
On the half-duplex end of the connection.

Full-duplex communications do not produce collisions. However, collisions often occur in half-duplex operations. When a connection has two different duplex configurations, the half-duplex end will experience late collisions. Collisions are found on Ethernet networks. Serial interfaces use technologies other than Ethernet.
Related questions:
  • If one end of an Ethernet connection is configured for full duplex and the other end of the connection is configured for half duplex, where would late collisions be observed?

title: Election of Designated Ports (STP)
content: All ports on the root bridge are designated ports. This is because the root bridge has the lowest cost to itself.

title: Election of Root Bridge (STP)
content: Switch with the lowest bridge ID (see Bridge ID Components) becomes root bridge. If two BIDs are the same, switch with lowest MAC address will win.

title: Election of Root Ports (STP)
content: Root port is selected based on the lowest overall cost (best path) to the root bridge. See Root Path Cost for calculating cost.

title: Enable BPDU guard
content: (config)#spanning-tree portfast bpduguard default     OR     (config-if)#spanning-tree bpduguard enable

title: Endpoint Security Solutions
content: REDIRECT:Which three Cisco products focus on endpoint security solutions

title: EtherChannel
content: Combines multiple physical links into a single logical link between two switches.

title: EtherChannel Advantages
content: No need for spanning tree recalculation when link goes down, no need to upgrade links to increase bandwidth, config can be done on the EtherChannel interface.

title: EtherChannel Load-balancing
content: Source to Destination IP, source to destination MAC.

title: EtherChannel Requirements
content: All ports need to be the same speed, duplex, VLAN info like native and allowed VLANs, and trunking mode.

title: EtherChannel Types
content: PAgP - Cisco Prop., can have max 8 active links. States - (See PAgP States). LACP - IEEE spec, can have max 8 active links, 8 standby links. States - (See LCAP States)

title: Exclude IPs from DHCP pool
content: ip dhcp excluded-address <start ip address> [end ip address range (optional)]

title: First Hop Redundancy Protocols (FHRP)
content: HSRP - Cisco prop., failover of first hop IPv4 device. (See HSRP for more info) HSRP for IPv6 - Same as HSRP but for IPv6. HSRP group has virtual MAC addr. derived from HSRP grp num and also virtual IPv6 link-local address. Periodic RAs are sent when HSRP grp is active. VRRPv2 - IPv4, one router is elected as master, rest are backups. VRRPv3 - Added support for IPv6. GLBP - Cisco Prop., allows load balancing. GLBP for IPv6 - Same thing but for IPv6. IRDP - Legacy, hosts locate routers that provide connectivity to other networks.

title: FlexConnect
content:
FlexConnect is a wireless solution for branch and remote office deployments, and allows you to control access points in a branch office from the corporate office through a WAN link, without deploying a controller in each office.

Connected mode - WLC is reachable, FlexConnect AP has CAPWAP connectivity with its WLC and can send traffic through CAPWAP tunnel.
Standalone mode - WLC in unreachable. FlexConnect AP can assume some of the WLC functions like switching client data locally and client authentication locally.

title: For a data center, what is the difference in the server virtualization data traffic compared with the traditional client-server model?
content: There are significant data exchanges between virtual servers.

title: Frame Check Sequence (FCS)
content: The switch checks the last field of the datagram against its own FCS calculations. FCS checks for errors to ensure the frame is free of physical and data link errors.

title: Hello Message
content: Part of HSRP. Hello messages are sent every 3 seconds by default. If no hello message is received for 10 seconds, the standby router will become the active one.

title: Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP)
content: Transparent failover of first hope device; router. Used within a grp of routers for selecting active device and standby device for gateway services to a LAN.

title: How does virtualization help with disaster recovery within a data center?
content: Support of live migration

title: HSRP
content: Cisco Proprietary Protocol. Uses active and standby routers. By default, device with the highest IPv4 addr is elected as the active router, except if a HSRP priority value is set. Priority is 100 by default, highest priority becomes active router. Active router sends Hello Messages every 3 seconds by default. Standby router becomes active one after 10 seconds if no hello message is received. No load balancing.

title: HSRP States
content: Initial - First state after config change or when interface first becomes available. Learn - Router has not determined the virtual IP addr and has not seen hello messages from the active router. It will be waiting for messages from the active router. Listen - The router knows the virtual IP addr, but the router is neither the active router nor the standby router. It listens for hello messages from those routers. Speak - The router sends periodic hello messages and actively participates in the election of the active and/or standby router. Standby - The router is a candidate to become the next active router and sends periodic hello messages. Active - The router won the election.

title: Hypervisor
content:
Functions of Hypervisors
  • To manage virtual machines
  • To allocate physical system resources to virtual machines

The hypervisor does not protect the hosting OS from malware. Neither does it allow sharing software across virtual machines. The hard drive of the supporting computer does not need to be partitioned to run virtual machines. The hypervisor creates and manages virtual machines on a host computer and allocates physical system resources to them.

title: ICMPv6 RA Message Flags
content: ICMPv6 RA messages contain two flags to indicate whether a workstation should use SLAAC, a DHCPv6 server, or a combination to configure its IPv6 address. These two flags are M flag and O flag. When both flags are 0 (by default), a client must only use the information in the RA message. When M flag is 0 and O flag is 1, a client should use the information in the RA message and look for the other configuration parameters (such as DNS server addresses) on DHCPv6 servers.

title: IEEE 802.1Q
content: For VLAN tag field, go to VLAN tag field. For untagged frames, go to VLAN types - native.

title: Ingress / Egress
content:
Ingress - entering the interface
Egress - exiting the interface

title: Interfaces missing in VLAN assignments
content: REDIRECT:Trunking

title: ip arp inspection validate src-mac (DAI)
content: Checks source MAC in Ethernet header against sender MAC in ARP body.

title: IP Routing
content: To allow inter-VLAN routing on a Layer 3 switch, run the ip routing command in the global config.

title: IPv4 Loopback Interface
content: A logical interface internal to the router. It is always in an UP state as long as the device is functioning properly.

title: IPv6 SLACC Default Gateway
content: link-local address of the router interface in the network.

title: LACP
content:
IEEE 802.3ad (Open standrd, NOT Cisco Proprietary).

LACP States

  • On - Force channel without LACP exchange.
  • Active - Active negotiation state, port init. negotiations by sending LACP packets.
  • Passive - Passive negotiation state, port receives & responds but does not initiate LACP negotiation. (Combinations: On-On, Active-Active, Active-Passive)

title: Link Aggregation Protocols
content: REDIRECT:EtherChannel Types

title: Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP)
content: Vendor-neutral neighbor discovery protocol like CDP, allows 3rd party network devices. Advertises its identity and capabilities to devices and receives info from a physically connected Layer 2 device.

title: Local AAA
content: Ideal for small networks where the username and password is stored in the router.

title: Lower sender port priority
content: Default port priority is 128. If 1 switch’s port were configured with a lower port priority, other switch’s port in forwarding state. The other port on S4 would be a blocking state, prevent loop.

title: Lowest overall cost to root bridge
content: REDIRECT:Root Port Election

title: MAC addr table full
content: Switch will treat all frames as unknown unicast and flood all incoming frames to all ports in the local VLAN.

title: Management Frames
content: For management frames by AP, see AP Broadcast Frames.

title: Management Interface Creation (only on the management device)
content: In global config, type interface vlan <vlan id>, then ip add <ip addr> <subnet>, no shutdown, then go back to global config,and type ip default-gateway <ip addr>

title: MIB Object ID
content:
Object IDentifiers (OID) uniquely identify managed objects in a MIB hierarchy. OIDs belonging to Cisco, are numbered as follows: .iso (1).org (3).dod (6).internet (1).private (4).enterprises (1).cisco (9). Therefore, the OID is 1.3.6.1.4.1.9.

To provide secure access to MIB objects, MIB uses Community Strings, which are like passwords.

Related questions:
  • Which feature provides secure access to MIB objects?

title: Min. Ethernet Frame Size
content: 64 bytes (any lower is treated as collision fragments/runt frames & discarded)

title: Mitigate VLAN attacks
content: Enable trunking manually, disable DTP, set native VLAN to unused VLAN.

title: mls qos trust cos
content: Sets the trusted state of an interface, such as voice.

title: Multiple equal-cost paths
content: When a switch has multiple equal-cost paths to the root bridge, root bridge is chosen using Lowest sender BID, Lowest sender port priority, Lowest sender port ID.

title: Native VLAN
content: REDIRECT:VLAN Types

title: Network Time Protocol (NTP)
content: A protocol that allows network devices to synchronize their time with an NTP server. NTP uses UDP port 123 and is documented in RFC 1305. End Device needs an IP or cannot connect to NTP server

title: no switchport
content: Converts a port into a routed port.

title: no switchport access vlan <vlan no.>
content: When the command no switchport access vlan <vlan id> command is issued, the interface associated with that VLAN returns to VLAN 1 (default vlan).

title: no switchport trunk native vlan
content: Reset native vlan of trunk.

title: Nonegotiate
content: Requires manual config of trunking or nontrunking. Trunk: Permanent trunking mode. switchport nonegotiate

title: NTP networks
content:
Use a hierarchical system of time sources. Each level is called a stratum. Stratum level is defined as the number of hop counts from the authoritative source. The synchronized time is distributed across the network by using NTP.
Stratum LevelDescription
0No delay, non-network high precision timekeeping devices. Eg, Atomic & GPS clocks. Most accurate authoritative time sources.
1Network devices that R directly connected to Auth time sources. Acts as the primary network time standard to stratum 2 devices using NTP.
2 and belowStratum 2 servers R connected to Stratum 1 devices through network connections. Stratum 2 devices, such as NTP clients, synchronize their time by using the NTP packets from Stratum 1 servers. They can also act as servers for Stratum 3 devices.
The max hop count is 15. Stratum 16 = unsynchronized.
Time servers on same stratum level can be configured to act as a peer with other time servers on the same stratum level for backup or verification of time.

title: PAgP
content:
Cisco Proprietary Protocol. PAgP packets are sent between EtherChannel-capable ports to negotiate the forming of a channel.

PAgP States

  • On - Force channel without PAgP exchanges.
  • Desirable - Active negotiating state, initiates negotiations by sending PAgP packets.
  • Auto - Passive negotiation state, receives & responds but does not initiate PAgP negotiation. (Combinations: On-On, Desire-Desire, Desire-Auto)

title: Port Security Violation
content:
shutdown (Default) - Port goes to error-disabled state, port LED off, send syslog msg, violation counter increases. Admin must manually shutdown and no shutdown the interface.
restrict - Drop packets until no. of secure MAC addresses decrease below max value or max value is increased. Sends syslog msg and increases violation counter.
protect - Least secure, same as restrict except no syslog msg and no violation counter increase. Packets with unknown source addresses will be dropped without notification.
Check using show port-security
If the MAC address of a device attached to the port differs from the list of secure addresses, then a port violation occurs.

To check the status of port-security violation of an interface, enter the command: show port-security

title: Port States
content: Blocking, Listening, Learning, Forwarding, Disabled. Blocking - Only receives BPDU, no MAC addr table updates, no forwarding data frames. Listening - Receives and sends BPDU, no MAC addr table updates, no forwarding data frames. Learning - Receives and sends BPDU, MAC addr table updates, no forwarding data frames. Forwarding - Receives and sends BPDU, MAC addr table updates, forwarding data frames. Disabled - Everything no

title: QoS
content: Quality of Service. Prioritise time-sensitive traffic types like voice and video over other types like email.

title: RADIUS
content: Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service (RADIUS) is a protocol and server software that provides user-based authentication for an organization. Users in a WLAN will enter username and password credentials that are verified by the RADIUS server before allowing access to the WLAN.

title: Remove only 1/all vlan from switch
content: See vlan deletion.

title: Reset Lost Password
content:
Need physical access to the switch/router.
Related questions:
  • What must an administrator have in order to reset a lost password on a router?

title: RESTful operations corresponding to HTTP methods
content:
RESTful operations correspond to the following HTTP methods (shown to the left with the RESTful operation on the right):
  • POST > Create
  • GET > Read
  • PUT/PATCH > Update
  • DELETE > Delete

Answer for: Which RESTFul operation corresponds to the HTTP GET method?

title: Root Bridge
content: A single switch which is used as a reference point for all path calculations. The root bridge is selected in an election process. (See Election of Root Bridge (STP))

title: Root Path Cost (STP)
content:
Link SpeedSTP Cost: IEEE 802.1D-1998 RSTP Cost: IEEE 802.1w-2004
10 Gbps22,000
1 Gbps (Gigabit Ethernet)420,000
100 Mbps (Fast Ethernet)19200,000
10 Mbps1002,000,000

title: Root Port Election
content:
The root port is the port closest to the root bridge in terms of overall cost (best path) to the root bridge. This overall cost is known as the internal root path cost. Paths with the lowest cost become preferred, and all other redundant paths are blocked.
(See Root Path Cost to see the path cost of each link type)

title: Routed Ports
content: Ports on a Layer 3 switch that are used for routing. For configuration, see no switchport.

title: Router-on-a-Stick
content: Where a router is being used to route traffic between vlans, and one connection between a router & switch serves all of the vlans. The interface on the router will have subinterfaces which connect to each vlan. To connect to a switch, you need to use trunking.

title: Router-on-a-Stick Configuration
content: Create the vlans (see VLAN creation), create mgmnt interface (see Management Interface Creation), configure access ports, configure trunking ports (see Trunking commands), then configure the subinterface & IP address (see Subinterface Configuration).

title: Router-on-a-Stick Disadvantages
content: Requires an extra router; Does not scale well beyond 50 VLANs due to network congestion.

title: Security for Wireless RTR
content: Upon powering up, change default username and password of the wireless router.

title: Shared secret password
content: Used to encrypt messages between the WLC and RADIUS server.

title: show cdp neighbors detail vs show cdp neighbors
content:
What info can be gathered from show cdp neighbors detail that cannot be found with show cdp neighbors?
IP address of neighbor.

title: show ip dhcp binding
content: Shows IPv4 addresses and assigned to hosts by DHCP server along with their MAC addresses.

title: show ip interface brief
content: Displays the IP configuration of switch ports.

title: Show SSH info
content: Use the command show ip ssh in priviledged mode.

title: show vlan brief
content: Displays VLAN assignment & membership for all switch ports.

title: shutdown/no shutdown
content: Disables/Enables a virtual or physical switch interface respectively.

title: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)
content:
An application layer protocol for exchanging management information between network devices. It allows network administrators to monitor and manage network performance, find and solve network problems, and plan for network growth.

VersionDescription
SNMPv1No encryption. Community string authentication
SNMPv2cNo encryption. Community string authentication
SNMPv3 noAuthNoPriv
Noencryption. Username authentication
SNMPv3 authNoPriv
Noencryption. HMAC-MD5 or HMAC-SHA authentication
SNMPv3 authPrivDES (56 bit), 3DES 168 bit or AES (128,192,256 bit) encryption.
HMAC-MD5 or HMAC-SHA authentication

title: SNMP Components / SNMP Operation
content:
1. SNMP manager
  2. SNMP agents (managed node)
    • Switches, routers, or any network device that requires management
  3. Management Information Base (MIB)
    • Stores data about the device and operational statistics (Authorized users only)

OperationDescription
get-requestRetrieves a value from a specific variable.
get-next-requestRetrieves a value from a variable within a table; the SNMP manager does not need to know the exact variable name. A sequential search is performed to find the needed variable from within a table.
get-bulk-requestRetrieves large blocks of data, such as multiple rows in a table, that would otherwise require the transmission of many small blocks of data.
get-responseReplies to a get-request, get-next-request, and set-request sent by a Network Management System (NMS).
set-requestStores a value in a specific variable.

title: SNMP Trap Messages
content: Unsolicited messages alerting the SNMP manager to a condition or event on the network such as a link being down. Trap-directed notifications reduce network and agent resources by eliminating the need for some of SNMP polling requests.

title: Spanning Tree Algorithm (STA)
content: Select root bridge > Block redundant path > Loop free topography > Link failure = recalculate path.

title: Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)
content: Prevent L2 loops which can result in broadcast storms by disabling redundant paths. Can calculate best path when there is a failure. No STP = Endless loop of frames + high CPU utilization n MAC address table instability.

title: SSH (Secure Shell)
content: Pretty much the same as Telnet but SSH has encryption so more secure.

title: SSH/Telnet Configuration
content: In the vty lines, enter transport input all / transport input ssh / transport input telnet.

title: Store-and-Forward Switching
content: Two characteristics: Error checking and Automatic buffering. Error checking does a frame check sequence (FCS) after receiving the whole frame. If the frame has no errors, it Is forwarded. Otherwise, it is dropped. Automatic Buffering allows flexibility for different Ethernet speeds.

title: STP Types
content: STP - Original IEEE version, assumes 1 spanning tree regardless of VLANs. PVST+ - Cisco enhancement of STP, provides separate tree instance for each VLAN, supports PortFast, UplinkFast, BackboneFast, BPU guard & filter, root and loop guards. RSTP - Faster upgrade of STP. Rapid PVST+ - Cisco enhancement of RSTP, each separate tree insurance supports the services above in PVST+. MSTP - IEEE standard, maps multiple VLANs to same spanning tree instance. MST - Same physical and logical topology as MSTP, provides 16 instances of RSTP and combines many VLANs into the same physical and logical topology as RSTP instance. Supports services like PVST+ above.

title: Subinterface Configuration
content: In the subinterface config (e.g. interface G0/0/1.10 for vlan 10), type encapsulation dot1Q <vlan id>, then type ip add <ip addr> <subnet mask>. (Good to put description too)

title: SVI inter-vlan routing benefits
content: Faster switching of packets, and there is no need for a connection to a router.

title: Switch Boot Up Sequence
content:
1. Switch loads and executes Power-On-Self-Test (POST)
  2. Switch loads boot loader software.
  3. Boot loader performs low-level CPU initialization.
  4. Boot loader initializes flash memory.
  5. Boot loader locates and loads default IOS image from BOOT environment variable.

title: Switch Buffers
content:
Switches have large frame buffers that allow data waiting to be transmitted to be stored so the data will not be dropped. This feature is beneficial especially if the incoming traffic is from a faster port than the egress port used for transmitting, and prevents premature frame discarding when network congestion occurs.
Related questions:
  • How do switch buffers affect network performance?

title: Switch Forwarding Methods
content: Store & forward: Check for errors, if err drop frame, auto buffering for duplex mismatch. Cut-through: Ignore errors, less latency.

title: Switch LED Indicators
content:
System LED: (Shows if system is receiving power & functioning properly)
ColourDescription
NILOff
GreenNormal Operation
AmberReceiving power, but not working properly

Redundant Power System (RPS) LED: (Shows the RPS status)
ColourDescription
NILOff / Improper Connection
GreenConnected, ready to give backup power
Blinking GreenConnected, backup power given to other device
AmberStandby mode, fault condition
Blinking AmberInternal power supply fails in switch, RPS give power

Port Status LED: (Indicates that the port status mode is selected when the LED is green. [Default mode])
ColourDescription
NILNo link / Port is shut down
GreenLink Present
Green-AmberPort is sending/receiving data, activity happening
AmberPort blocked, preventing loop in forward domain (e.g., STP blocked port), no data forwarding (Ports remain in this state for 30s when activated)
Blinking AmberPort blocked, prevent possible loop in forward domain

Port Duplex LED: (Indicates that the port duplex mode is selected when the LED is green)
ColourDescription
NILHalf-duplex mode
GreenFull-duplex mode

Port Speed LED: (Indicates that the port speed mode is selected)
ColourDescription
NIL10 Mbps
Green100 Mbps
Blinking Green1000 Mbps

Power over Ethernet (PoE) Mode LED: (PoE supported, PoE mode LED present)
ColourDescription
NILPoE mode unselected, port not denied power, not in fault mode
PoE off
GreenPoE mode selected, Port LEDs shows diff colours, diff meanings
PoE on
Green-AmberPoE denied, power to be supplied to powered device exceeds switch power capacity
AmberPoE disabled on port
Blinking AmberPoE mode unselected, >= 1 port denied power or PoE fault

title: Switch Mode
content: Between Switch and Router/Switch, use trunk.

title: Switch Operation
content:
Switches use their CAM table which maps MAC addresses to ports (interface) to make frame forwarding decisions.

When a frame is received, the switch checks if the Source MAC address is in the CAM table, if not, it adds it and its port to the table. Otherwise, it sends the frame to the port associated with that MAC address in addr table.
If the destination MAC address is not in the CAM table, the switch broadcasts the frame to all ports except the ingress port. Otherwise, it sends it to the port associated with that MAC address in the CAM table.

title: Switch Ports
content: For when assigned VLAN is deleted, go to VLAN deletion.

title: Switch Verification commands
content:
show interfaces : disp. interface stat and config.
show startup-config: disp. current startup config.
show interfaces interface switchport: Display encapsulation type, voice VLAN ID, access mode VLAN, Verify Trunk Encapsulation, etc.
show running-config: Display current running config.
show flash: Display info about flash file sys.
show version: Display sys. hardware and software stat.
show history: disp. history of command entered.
show ip[v6] interface : disp. IP info about an interface.
show mac address-table: disp. MAC address table.

title: Switch Virtual Interface (SVI) Inter-VLAN Routing
content: An SVI needs to be created for each VLAN.

title: Switching
content: REDIRECT:Switch Operation

title: Switchport commands
content:
Enter switchport mode first. can be access or trunk.
Access: switchport mode access Trunk: switchport mode trunk
Allow VLANs on trunks: switchport trunk allowed vlan (NOTE: ONLY the VLANs listed will be allowed)

title: Telnet
content: Sends everything in plain text, including usernames & passwords. Use SSH instead as it's more secure.

title: Telnet Configuration
content: REDIRECT:SSH/Telnet Configuration.

title: Telnet Port
content: TCP port 23

title: Transport Input
content: Specifies which connection (SSH/Telnet/both) to allow on vty lines. To configure, go to vty lines (line vty 0-15) then type transport input <all | ssh | telnet>

title: Trunking
content: Trunk ports do not show in show vlan brief as they do not belong to a vlan. Trunk port sends/expects to receive tagged traffic.  | CFI | VID (2 bytes, 3 bits, 1 bit, 12 bits) Tag: |ethernet type(0X8100) | Pri | CFI | VID| (2 bytes, 3 bits, 1 bit, 12 bits).

title: Two-Tier topographly
content:
In a typical two-tier spine-leaf topology, every lower-tier switch, or the leaf layer, is connected to each of the top-tier switches, or the spine layer in a full-mesh topology.

However, the lower-tier switches are not connected to each other due to scalability issues in large networks.

title: Types of Wireless Networks
content: WPAN - Wireless Personal-Area Network, low powered transmitters, short range network, based on 802.15 standard and 2.4 GHz. WLAN - Wireless LAN, uses transmitters to cover medium sized network. Suitable for home, office and campus. Based on 802.11 standard, uses 2.4 or 5 GHz.  WMAN - Wireless Metropolitan Area Network, uses transmitters to cover a larger geographic area, suitable for cities / districts, use specific licensed frequencies. WWAN - Wireless Wide Area Networks, uses transmitters to cover an extensive geographic area, suitable for national and global comms, also use specific licensed frequencies.

title: Untagged frames
content: Use native vlan (see VLAN types - native)

title: URI and URL
content: A URI is a string of characters that identifies a specific network resource while a URL defines the network location of a specific resource on the network.

title: Verification Commands
content:
show running-config - Shows currently running configuration.
show ip interface - Shows IP configuration of interfaces.
show vlan - Shows VLAN configuration.
show interfaces trunk - Shows trunk configuration, along with native VLAN.

EtherChannel


show etherchannel summary (Priviledged Exec) - Verify ports used in an EtherChannel

title: Violation modes
content: REDIRECT:Port Security Violation.

title: VLAN benefits
content: Smaller bcast domains, more security as devices can only comm. in same vlan, improved network efficiency & perf., cost reduction as no need to buy switches, simple project & app mgment. Separate functions makes specialised apps easier.

title: VLAN communication
content: Devices can only communicate within the same vlan. e.g. broadcast cannot go from vlan 20 to vlan 30.

title: VLAN creation
content: In global config, enter vlan <vlan id>, then name <vlan-name>

title: VLAN deletion
content: To delete only 1 vlan, in global config, enter no vlan <vlan id>. To delete all vlans, in exec mode, run delete flash:vlan.dat. Ports won't be disabled, but they will just stop communicating with the attached devices.

title: VLAN double-tagging attack
content:
A VLAN Hopping Attack where the attacker embeds a hidden 802.1Q tag inside the frame that already has an 802.1Q tag. This allows the frame to go to a VLAn that the original 802.1Q tag did not specify.

The native and user VLANs being the same makes it vulnerable to VLAN double-tagging attacks.

title: VLAN tag field
content: Type - Value for the tag protocol ID value. VLAN ID - VLAN number. User Priority - Value that supports level or service implementation. Canonical Format Identifier - Identifier that enables Token Ring frames to be carried across Ethernet links.

title: VLAN types
content:
• Default (vlan 1, default mgment vlan)
  • data (separate network into groups of users or devices), management (for SSH, Telnet, HTTP(S), SNMP)
  • native (default vlan 1, used for trunks, untagged across trunks, provide a common identifier across trunks)
  • voice (for VoIP, delay < 150ms, priority)

title: What is a function of the data plane of a network device?
content: Forwarding traffic flows

title: What is REST?
content: Architecture style for designing web service applications. REST is not a protocol or service, but rather a style of software architecture for designing web service applications.

title: What is the function of the key contained in most RESTful APIs?
content:
It is used to authenticate the requesting source.
Related questions:
  • Function of key in REST APIs?

title: What is the most widely used API for web services?
content: REST

title: What mitigation plan is best for thwarting a DoS attack that is creating a MAC address table overflow?
content: Enable port security.

title: What pre-populates the FIB on Cisco devices that use CEF to process packets?
content: The Routing Table

title: Which cloud model provides services for a specific organization or entity?
content: A private cloud

title: Which component in a traditional infrastructure device provides Layer 2 and Layer 3 functions to create data paths within a network?
content: Control plane

title: Which is a characteristic of a Type 1 hypervisor?
content: Installed directly on a server?Explanation: Type 1 hypervisors are installed directly on a server and are known as 'bare metal' solutions giving direct access to hardware resources. They also require a management console and are best suited for enterprise environments.?

title: Which Layer 2 attack will result in legitimate users not getting valid IP addresses?
content: DHCP Starvation

title: Which network traffic management technology is a basic element in SDN implementations?
content: OpenFlow

title: Which one of the following statements describes the behaviour of a switch when the MAC address/CAM table is full?
content: It treats all frames as unknown unicast and floods all incoming frames to all ports within the local VLAN.

title: Which statement describes the concept of cloud computing?
content: Separation of application from hardware

title: Which three Cisco products focus on endpoint security solutions? (Choose three.)
content: Web Security Appliance, Email Security Appliance, NAC Appliance.

title: Which two concepts is for switch ports to connect only end devices and not to another switch?
content: Edge Port, PortFast

title: Which two layers of the OSI model are associated with SDN network control plane functions that make forwarding decisions?
content:
Layer 2, Layer 3

Explanation: The SDN control plane uses the Layer 2 ARP table and the Layer 3 routing table to make decisions about forwarding traffic.

title: Which type of Hypervisor is implemented when a user with a laptop running the Mac OS installs a Windows virtual OS instance?
content:
Type 2

Explanation: Type 2 hypervisors, also know as hosted hypervisors, are installed on top of an existing operating system, such as Mac OS, Windows, or Linux.

title: Which type of hypervisor would most likely be used in a data center?
content:
Type 1

Explanation: The two type of hypervisors are Type 1 and Type 2. Type 1 hypervisors are usually used on enterprise servers. Enterprise servers rather than virtualized PCs are more likely to be in a data center.

title: Why Active Clients for IPv6 is 0
content: The state is not maintained by the DHCPv6 server under stateless mode. When the command ipv6 nd other-config-flag is set, the DHCPv6 does not maintain state information. (Stateless)

title: Why DHCPDISCOVER is broadcast
content: Client doesn't have IP address yet to send unicast messages.

title: Why DHCPREQUEST is broadcast
content: Client may have received offers from multiple servers, broadcast is to decline those offers.

title: Why ISP assigns DHCP to Wireless Router in SOHO environment
content: Easy IP address management

title: Windows failed to get IPv4 address
content: Windows will automatically set the IP address to start with 168.254.

title: Wireless antennas
content: Omnidirectional - 360 deg coverage, ideal for home, open office area, conference room, outdoors. Directional - Focus radio signal in one direction, stronger signal strength in one direction and reduced in other directions. Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) - Multiple antennas to increase bandwidth for 802.11n/ac/ax networks, up to eight transmit and receive antennas can be used.

title: Wireless network not showing
content: Access point may be operating in active mode.

title: Wireless security modes
content: Personal - One shared password for all users. Enterprise -Users need to login with username and password, RADIUS server authenticates them.
